full_title_en: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Belching Disorders
medium_description_en: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of excessive supragastric or gastric belching.
instructions_en:
Use in patients with symptoms suggestive of a belching disorder, such as bothersome belching from the esophagus or stomach more than 3 days per week for at least 6 months.

Patients with any of the following features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though a belching disorder may be present: 

  • Signs or symptoms of GI bleeding.

  • Unexplained iron deficiency anemia.

  • Unintentional weight loss.

  • Palpable abdominal mass or lymphadenopathy on exam.

  • Family history of gastric cancer and no recent upper endoscopy.

  • Dysphagia.

  • Persistent vomiting.

how_to_use.use_case_en: Patients presenting with recurrent upper GI symptoms suggestive of a belching disorder for at least the past 6 months. The diagnosis of a belching disorder should be made by clinical history and physical examination.
how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• Belching is a frequent manifestation of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

  • There are two subtypes of belching disorders: supragastric belching, characterized by rapid antegrade and retrograde flow of air in the esophagus, which does not reach the stomach, and gastric belching, in which air originates from the stomach and is permitted to move in a retrograde manner as a result of transient relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES).

  • Observation of air swallowing on physical examination is supportive of a belching disorder. When the patient is asked to bite down on a pencil or pen, the belching will stop.

  • Esophageal impedance/manometry can assist in the diagnosis of a belching disorder and may distinguish between supragastric belching and gastric belching.
how_to_use.why_use_en:
• Helps to make a diagnosis of a belching disorder.

  • Helps to distinguish symptoms from other common disorders, such as GERD.

  • Helps to guide management of a belching disorder based on subtype (supragastric belching vs gastric belching).

next_steps.advice_en:
If diagnostic criteria are not met (negative):

Symptoms are unlikely to be caused by a belching disorder. Consider further assessment for other diseases, or a different functional GI disorder.

If meets diagnosis (positive):

Symptoms are likely due to a belching disorder. Provide reassurance and explanation of symptoms to the patient.
next_steps.management_en:
Management of belching disorders should be based on the subcategorization.

For supragastric belching:

  • Speech therapy.

  • Diaphragmatic breathing.

  • Behavioral therapy (e.g. cognitive behavioral therapy, hypnosis).

For gastric belching:

  • Avoidance of carbonated beverages.

  • Speech therapy.

  • Diaphragmatic breathing.

  • Simethicone.

  • Baclofen.
next_steps.critical_actions_en:
• This calculator should only be used in patients after appropriate organic, systemic, and metabolic causes have been ruled out after careful investigation.

  • Note: Other GI conditions, such as GERD, may coexist with belching disorders.

about.formula_en:
To fulfill the Rome IV criteria for belching disorders,* patient must have the following (for 3 months prior with symptom onset ≥6 months ago):

  1. Excessive supragastric belching: Bothersome (i.e., severe enough to impact on usual activities) belching from the esophagus more than 3 days a week.

  2. Excessive gastric belching: Bothersome (i.e., severe enough to impact on usual activities) belching from the stomach more than 3 days a week.

*Note:

  1. Supragastric belching is supported by observing frequent, repetitive belching.

  2. Gastric belching has no established clinical correlate.

  3. Objective intraluminal impedance measurement can be used to distinguish supragastric from gastric belching.
about.evidence_based_medicine_en:
The Rome criteria were initially developed as a way to classify and diagnose the various disorders of gut brain interaction (DGBI) such as functional dyspepsia, functional constipation, and irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) based primarily on symptoms. Changes in the Rome IV criteria for belching disorders include:

  1. Aerophagia is considered a historical term, because not all cases with belching arise from swallowing air

The development of the Rome IV questionnaires began with a survey of 1,162 adults without gastrointestinal disorders to determine the frequency in the US general population of various gastrointestinal symptoms. The 90th percentile of symptom frequency was used to define what was considered an abnormal frequency of symptoms. Based on this, diagnostic questionnaires were created and reviewed by clinical experts.

creator_info.about_en: Douglas Drossman, MD, is professor emeritus of medicine and psychiatry at the University of North Carolina School of Medicine. He is founder, President Emeritus and Chief of Operations of the Rome Foundation. He is also the founder of the Drossman Center for the Education and Practice of Biopsychosocial Care and Drossman Consulting, LLC. Dr. Drossman has written over 500 articles and book chapters, has published two books, a GI procedure manual and a textbook of functional GI disorders (Rome I-IV), and serves on six editorial and advisory boards.

Lin Chang, MD is responsible for the oversight and coordination of the Rome IV calculators on MDCalc. She is a Professor of Medicine at the Vatche and Tamar Manoukian Division of Digestive Diseases at UCLA and is a member of the Rome Foundation Board of Directors.

The Rome Foundation is an independent not for profit 501(c) 3 organization that provides support for activities designed to create scientific data and educational information to assist in the diagnosis and treatment of Disorders of Gut-Brain Interaction (DGBI), also known as functional gastrointestinal (GI) disorders. Their mission is to improve the lives of people with DGBI. Over the last 3 decades, the Rome organization has sought to legitimize and update our knowledge of the DGBIs. This has been accomplished by bringing together scientists and clinicians from around the world to classify and critically appraise the science of GI function and dysfunction. This knowledge permits clinical scientists to make recommendations for diagnosis and treatment that can be applied in research and clinical practice. Diagnosis is based on the use of symptom-based criteria which are used in clinical trials and daily practice.
